This argument seems to be devolving rather quickly into pointless 
nit-picking about trivial issues.

I have personally taught JUnit to 75 - 100 different programmers over the 
last several years.  I can't recall any of these people being very confused 
about the difference between a failure (one of your assertions failed) and 
an error (something else went wrong).  Nor can I recall anyone having much 
difficulty grasping the concept of setUp() as a place for common code that 
gets run right before each test method.  You don't have to like them, but 
these are not hard concepts.

Finally, I don't pretend to know how everyone out there is using JUnit.  But 
with XP-style development the only situations I can think of where you would 
suddenly get 100 errors OR failures that you needed to parse through are:

1) Lots of your "unit" tests really depend on some fragile/unreliable 
external resource (bad)

2) Many tests are tightly coupled and are exercising the same lines of code 
(bad)

3) Someone made a LOT of edits in between test runs (bad)

The strength of JUnit lies not in its reporting capabilities, but in the 
ease with which you can move seamlessly--almost effortlessly--between 
writing tests, writing code, and running tests to check your assumptions and 
measure your progress.

Jeff Nielsen
Digital Focus
www.digitalfocus.com

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Cedric Beust" <cbeust@...>

I have always found the difference between ERROR and FAILURE confusing and I
bet that except for JUnit experts such as yourself, nobody can really
explain it.

Assuming that it's important to know whether a test failed because of an
assert of an unexpected exception (a dubious proposition in the first place
since when a test fails, you are going to check out the stack trace anyway
and find out exactly where it failed), it would certainly have been better
to name them differently.

<and>

This is certainly an improvement over the current JUnit behavior, but I
still find that:

101 TESTS, 1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPPED

is much clearer...
